Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Dynamics and Disorder Effects in Bose-Einstein Condensates, Degenerate Fermi Gases and Mixtures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs), degenerate Fermi gases and Bose-Fermi mixtures offer unique opportunities for the investigation of nonlinear dynamics in quantum systems. The PI and his group have developed new experimental techniques to generate and observe quantum shock waves in BECs. Extensions of these techniques will be employed to investigate extreme nonlinear quantum dynamics and disorder phenomena in new and unexplored regimes. For example, two-dimensional shocks in BECs are predicted to exhibit intriguing richness of dynamical phenomena including a proliferation of quantized vortices at the shock front, a variety of instabilities, a novel phase diagram for oblique shock, and potentially a transition to a turbulent regime. The quantum shock experiments will provide much needed benchmark tests for theoretical treatments of quantum dynamics. In addition, degenerate Fermi gases as well as Bose-Fermi mixtures will be employed for the investigation of new physics in the presence of disorder potentials and to address central questions of quantum percolation.

While all the experiments will be conducted with ultracold quantum degenerate gases, the importance of this research goes beyond the field of atomic physics. A precise understanding of the dynamics revealed by the experiments is essential for a variety of other systems governed by a nonlinear equation similar to the one applicable to BECs. Dispersive shock waves exist in plasmas, shallow water systems, and nonlinear optical media, to name a few. Nonlinear phenomena in optical media are of great importance e.g. for high-speed communication. The investigations of disorder phenomena will be highly relevant for developing a detailed understanding of complex materials such as glass phases, dirty superconductors, granular metals, etc. Disorder effects also play important roles in various nontrivial acoustics and optics phenomena. The experiments allow students at all levels to gain experience in an unusually broad range of modern physics and lab techniques. Ongoing cooperation with local, national and international theory groups provide the students with ample opportunities for exchanging scientific ideas. The PI's lab is also actively participating in a variety of educational and outreach activities, including regular visits from high school classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Clouds of atoms cooled to temperatures near zero Kelvin are a powerful tool  for investigating quantum mechanics. Quantum mechanics describes matter as being  a duality ,  having both a wave and a particle nature at the same time. One fascinating prediction of quantum mechanics is superfluidity, i.e. the fact that certain fluids can flow around objects or through tiny channels unimpeded, without viscosity. While superfluidity in single-component fluids such as liquid Helium II has been under intense investigation for many decades, ultracold quantum gases provide new handles for the  study of this phenomenon in completely new and unexplored regimes. In the frame of this proposal we have conducted a first thorough experimental and theoretical analysis of superfluid-superfluid counterflow, i.e. the physics of two distinguishable superfluids penetrating each other. We have discovered intriguingly rich nonlinear dynamics. A modulational instability plays a key role in the observed dynamics. We devised a technique that harnesses this instability to generate trains of solitons in the fluids, i.e. clusters of atoms of one type that do not disperse into a background of atoms of a second type but instead effectively behave like one particle (Fig. 1). We detected several types of these solitons, including an oscillating dark-dark soliton that had never been observed before. We conducted the first detailed studies of the properties of solitons generated by two-component counterflow, including their motion when confined in a trap (Fig. 2), their stability, their tendency to group together with other solitons and form “soliton molecules”, their behavior when encountering barriers, etc. Our experiments have stimulated an accompanying theoretical program conducted by an international group of theoretical physicists and applied mathematicians. While ultracold quantum gases provide a unique environment to study solitons, an understanding of the underlying physics is important for several other systems as well. For example, related optical solitons can propagate through nonlinear media and may play an important role for future telecommunication technologies.

Furthermore, in our experiment we implemented a laser setup that provides a flexible means to modify the dispersion relation of atoms. The dispersion relation connects the energy of a particle to its momentum and determines its motional behavior. For example, the dispersion of a free particle is parabolic, while the dispersion of a particle confined in a crystal lattice has a periodic band structure. Using suitably tailored laser fields, one can engineer various forms of dispersions and study their effect on the dynamics. The scheme used in our experiments leads to a coupling between the motion of the atoms and an internal property, the spin. We have investigated this spin-orbit coupling in a set of prototypical experiments. This research explores possibilities  for ultracold atoms  to serve as a model system for advanced condensed matter systems in which quantum mechanics plays a fundamental role. A detailed understanding of quantum mechanics will be essential for further progress in many areas, including the development of next-generation sensors, novel schemes of quantum computation, the development of advanced materials, etc.
